DOC.HEAD: Fires in Suburban Post Offices Destroy Christmas Mail
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 pieces of Christmas mail were destroyed in four post office fires that officials said were the work of arsonists. Flammable liquid was poured into mail slots and ignited Sunday morning, burning almost all the contents, police and fire officials said. Several grass fires also were set in this suburb between Dallas and Fort Worth. ``They're all arson. We're dead sure of that. The same person or persons did all of these,'' said Stephen Lea, deputy fire marshal. Postmaster Mike Larntz said 1,000 to 2,000 pieces of mail were destroyed. ``Anyone who dropped mail in those boxes after the last collection should consider that mail gone,'' Larntz said. ``Any salvageable mail, anything we can identify, we will make an attempt to send anything back to the sender or receiver.'' No injuries were reported. Damage to each of the post offices was estimated at $5,000, not counting the mail. Walls, glass and ceilings were burned at the four post office buildings, Larntz said. One was closed Monday because of fire damage, he said.
